reviewText: At last! ATTACK OF THE CRAB MONSTERS- Typical land crabs, effected by radiation, grow into enormous monsters! They are able to ingest humans, adding their consciousness to their own collective mind! Can a small band of scientists stop these cranky crustaceans before they conquer our planet? Russell Johnson (IT CAME FROM OUTER SPACE, THIS ISLAND EARTH) co-stars. NOT OF THIS EARTH- An alien comes to Earth in search of human blood! His planet is dying, so he's been sent to turn us into livestock for mass consumption! Beverly Garland co-stars as Nurse Nadine. Also stars Jonathan Haze (LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS, THE TERROR) as Bruno, and Dick Miller (BUCKET OF BLOOD, LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS) as a doomed vacuum cleaner salesman! WAR OF THE SATELLITES- Our satellites are being destroyed by some unknown force! An alien ship lands on earth! A scientist is killed and replaced w/ a duplicate! World-wide catastrophic events erupt! The UN debates endlessly! Can we survive this alien onslaught? Stars Susan Cabot (WASP WOMAN), Dick Miller, and Vin Ve Sota (ATTACK OF THE GIANT LEECHES). Watch for Roger Corman himself at the helm of mission control! Three great prints of three classic Roger Corman epics. Each film shows how Corman could make the best of an extremely low budget. Simple, but effective stories, coupled w/ imagination and a love of filmmaking result in a fun, always entertaining experience... Plus- Interviews, commentaries, and scads (25) of trailers for Corman films!...

reviewText: Cheesy 50's Drive-in type movies. Serious acting. Fake-looking monsters, unbelievable science. But, it's what the family likes on Friday nite Horror Movie night. Pop some Popcorn, and get ready for some really cheesy Horror. At approx 8 bucks a movie for the Triple-pack....you can't go wrong. And it WAS Roger Corman in the 50s,...who was the King of Cheesy movies.Delivery, in a larger Amazon order, took about 6 days. Video Quality is very good, and if you have a Blu-ray DVD player, or any other brand of "Up-scaling" DVD player, the video quality will be a pleasant surprise.
summary: You have to be into this Genre to like them.

reviewText: Shout Factory brings us the latest installation of Roger Corman titles on this scifi 3 set - 3 movies on 2 discs. I believe 2 movies will be on one disc and the 2nd disc will have one movie and lots of trailers.which Cliff Mac said this DVD would have..The movies run roughly 65-80 minutes max. The movies are Attack of the Crab Monsters, War of the Satellites and Not of this Earth (the original 1957 version)ATTACK OF THE CRAB MONSTERS - this is about a group of people (including Russell Johnson, the Professor from Gilligans Island) on an Island looking for some lost seamen and encounter giant atomic bomb created crabs. The 1950s was the nuclear age , what with the likes of Godzilla, Them , & other atomic monsters, why not crabs ? The film is very enjoyable for the most part, of course the crabs are the stars of this film. This is a fun little B monster movie. Listen for the crabs when they use their victims voices to lure more people in...WAR OF THE SATELLITES - Admittedly I have never seen this film - but from what I have read it contains unseen aliens taking over humans to sabotage a space flight. Both John Stanley and Michael Weldon's books have entries and neither seem to be high on it. We can all judge for ourselves. Dick Miller is in this so it cant be all bad can it ?NOT OF THIS EARTH - the original 1957 has the late great Beverly Garland against Paul "the Alien who needs blood to survive " Birch - He needs blood for his entire race and comes to Earth to get it. This film contains some of those pancake monsters from It Conquered the World and It Came Without Warning. Its a lot of fun, a harmless low budget science fiction film. It can be a little slow at times but overall if you are into Corman films, you'll probably like this one tooBonus material hasnt been announced yet but I expect Shout Factory to do the best they can to supply as much supplements as possible. Id love to see an interview with Roger Corman about these picturesThe transfers from what I gather will be in their original aspect ratios. I am certain Attack of the Crab Monsters on this disc will surpass the Allied Artists DVD that came out years ago and was a lousy transfer..Overall this will be a fun set of 3 Corman sci fi classics from his early that will be a nice way to relax on a rainy day or quiet evening.The following is an update as for as bonus features for this setROGER CORMAN'S SCI-FI CLASSICS Special Features:A SALUTE TO ROGER CORMAN - featuring new interviews with Roger Corman, Peter Fonda, Peter Bogdanovich, Joe Dante and many more.Audio Commentaries on ATTACK OF THE CRAB MONSTERS and NOT OF THIS EARTH (1957) with Tom Weaver, John Brunas and Mike Brunas, authors of Universal HorrorsTHE ROGER CORMAN TRAILER COLLECTION features over 25 trailers produced and directed by Roger CormanAll-new interview with Roger Corman looking back at all three films.Thanks again to the guys at Shout who have pleased many genre fans all over the world with their releases...This will be a GREAT SET - period...++ And it is - the 2 main films that I like Not of this Earth and Attack of the Crab Monsters - are both in widescreen - both are gorgeous transfers while the WOTS is a full frame print but has lots of Corman directed trailers...
summary: A MUST for classic horror scifi fans..a great classic trilogy
Title: N/A

reviewText: Three in one, brief enough to watch in one sitting.Attack of the Crab Monsters has a surprisingly good concept, albeit with big rubbery monsters.  I liked the idea of the creatures literally undermining the island they're all marooned on, and their absorption of the dwindling survivors.  Yes, the monsters look fake, that's part of their charm.  Those of us who grew up watching these types of `monsters' aren't any different than this generation and their CGI cartoony looking creatures.Not of This Earth also has a creepy concept and an equally creepy alien to go along with it.  Love the eyes!  It's surprising just how much you can achieve with very little money and even less time.War of the Satellites is perhaps the cheapest looking one of the bunch (the crew uses lounge chairs with spindly legs during takeoff.  Why bother to strap into something that's obviously not even bolted to the floor!  I suppose they thought they were `futuristic' enough to serve their purpose).  The only thing cheaper than this would be a View-Master!  But it was fun.  They just don't make them like this anymore.  And why would they...A keeper times 3!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Corman was the king of no money, low budget films and this collection proves it. Special effects, when there are any, are childish even for those times. However, the story line, especially "Not Of This Earth" & "Attack Of The Crab Monsters" are not too far fetched. If they were produced with better special effects they might have been considered good sci-fi classics, but, given what he had to work with they are nothing more than curiosities at best. For instance, the creature which is let loose towards the end of "Not of..." is so stupid and ineffective, besides seeing the wires, it should have been left out entirely. It ruins what credibility the film had. The actors do the best they can with some decent performances turned in by virtual unknowns. Corman re-made this one with an updated campy version showing a lot of "T & A" starring a porn star and a better budget but didn't hit the mark either. He turned it into a stupid version of the original, if that is possible."Attack Of The Crab Monsters" again with a very low budget and stock footage, has some interesting characters, like the Professor from Gilligan's Island, Russell Johnson. The dialog is stupid and calling the only female in very tight clothes who is suppose to be a scientist "honey" doesn't work either. Unfortunately,the creatures are the problem, also. Stupid looking. However, this could have been a good classic with more money. The premise is good, radioactivity from the bombs mutating crabs to enormous size and intelligence, sucking the brains from its' victims and knowing their secrets(we did see this in "Starship Troopers"), but, no clear reason why they are destroying the island.If you can overlook this collection's short comings it might be worth a one time look. But don't spend too much money on it.

reviewText: Well worth the price for the excellent print of "Attack of the Crab Monsters."  Years ago I ordered from Amazon a VSH tape of it that looked like a bad bootleg copy."Attack of the Crab Monsters" has to be my favorite Roger Corman B monster movie.  I still remember the first time I saw it one long ago Friday, after school on the local late afternoon movie.  What a great way to start a weekend watching this fun film.  Everything thing works for me in this movie from the music, direction, acting and even the special effects.  What really impressives me even today is the atmosphere of doom that sets in from the start of the movie.  The Crab Monster's ability to project the voices of the victims that it has already consumed still creeps me out.  And while the giant grab monster did look a bit silly to me I was already too hook on the film for it to matter."Not of This Earth" is no doubt Corman's most popular B movie (have been remade twice) from the 50's.  This one always left a bad taste in my mouth and for many years I really did not care to re watch it.  I think the murder of the teenage girl at the film's very beginning got the film off on the wrong foot for me.  Then the female vampire/alien's later death from rabies infected blood proved to be a little too much for my young sensibilities.  Looking back on it I am surprised at what my parents allowed me to watch on TV uncensored.  Today I can watch the film with a new attitude and yes the two scenes that upset me as a child still bother me today but now I can enjoy for what it does do right and I am glad to add it to my film collection."War of the Satellites" is the weakest of the three films in this collection.  While I loved this film as a child I was surprised by how little interest it held for me in my recent viewing.  The fact that the film is really dated doesn't bother me.  Rarely does have an effect on me when I am watching old films.  The story ideas were good but so beyond the films budget that it just doesn't work any more.  Then there is Dick Miller as the "handsome young" rocket expert.  Boy was he miscasted as the film's hero.  But Richard Devon was very good as the bad guy.My only real problem with this collection are the commentaries provided in the extras.  Everyone one speaking seems to have nothing but comptempt for these films.  Why do a commentary (I know they are being paid to do so) if you don't have much regard for the product.

reviewText: If you like Sea Food, you'll love Attack of the Crab Monsters. Body snatching anyone?  You'll love War of the Satellites and Not of this World.  I got into bad movies as a kid and learned to appreciate them through MST3k, but there's nothing like watching them all gussied up and remastered in Black and White glory like this.  Forget the cheese of the effects and some wooden line delivery from a script written over a lunch break.  Just sit back and watch and enjoy and you might realize that the story was actually pretty good and a good sight better than our own Michael Bay!
summary: Great Waste of Time, but that's a good thing.

reviewText: I've waited so long for quality issues of these titles, and I'm not disappointed.  After years of bootlegged fifth-generation prints, we finally have what look like brand-new anamorphic copies.  And the films are delightful (I'm essentially referring to crab monsters & not of this earth), perfect representations of low-budget fifties sci-fi.  (Crab Monsters was the highest grossing low-budget production of 1957)  Now all we need are similar editions of THE UNDEAD & IT CONQUERED THE WORLD.  (I have to admit to relishing my old AMC full-screen edition of THE UNDEAD, as it gives full justice to statuesque Alision Hayes, but quality will out, and I'd rather see an ultra-clean, ultra-sharp anamorphic copy like these two)  I haven't watched War of the Satellites, and it's a 4:3 transfer.  My interest isn't that great, but I'm bound to catch it eventually.

reviewText: You will get tree Roger Coreman Grande B Science Fiction movie in glorious black and white.  You will get the original "Not of This Earth."  Why they ever made that re-make, I'll never know.  But if you never saw the original, you need to see the original.  Actor Robert Shane (Inspector Henderson from "The Adventures of Superman" TV Series from the 1950's appears in this movie as  the head of Ground Control on Earth. Not a lead role, but not a small part either.  Actor Russell Johnson (The Professor from "Gilligan's Island) appears in "Attack of the Crab Monsters" as one of the scientists.These movies were made on a low shoe-string budget, but the writing and acting carries these movies.  There are movies today made with elaborate budgets, but this does not make up or compensate for the lesser quality of writing and acting in today's movies.
summary: A Triple Grabe B SciFi Movies Set Grand Slammer

reviewText: This has three of Roger Corman's movies. One is a classic, the other two are not. I got this for Not of This Earth (1957), which does not seem to be available separately. The remake is, but I didn't want that one. The other two just came with the packaging. Disc One has an interview of Roger Corman. Disc One has Attack of the Crab Monsters and Not of This Earth. Disco two has 25 trailers and War of the Satellites feature.ATTACK OF THE CRAB MONSTERS (1957). stars Richard Garland and Russell Johnson. Choice words for this are bottom-feeder, one of the worst Roger Corman films. However, viewing it, I found it not as horrible as other reviews have made it out to be. It is entertaining with some intriguing ideas, such as the victims of these giant crabs live on in the crabs' minds telepathically projecting their thoughts through metal objects. They become the crab. Scientists come to an obscure island somewhere near Eniwetok, South Pacific. They are the second expedition. The first disappeared. They come to exam the radiation's effects on the island. They have a botanist, geologist, zoologists, etc., and radio technicians, as well as ordinary seamen, part of a demolition team. The island slowly disappears from the giant crabs demolishing the island. Of course members of the team are eaten and absorbed by the crabs-- no bones left. After several attacks and theories given as to why they are so huge, they discover that electricity kills the monsters. But the crabs are smart, they absorb the minds of the scientists after all, so they avoid the traps and trick others. But when the expedition is reduced to two members the crabs die from a radio tower falling on them. It seems to me, to be a pretty good film, The models for the crabs were awkward, and there wasn't enough character development. A short film, only 63 minutes. Most reviewers in movie books hate this movie, but The New Encyclopedia of Science Fiction (James Gunn) liked it, and The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction (Clute and Nicholls) has positive things to say about it, yet the 1979 edition of that book called it one Corman's worst films, later editions were more positive. Halliwell calls it a bottom-feeder.NOT OF THIS EARTH (1957) Stars Paul Birch, Beverley Garland, and others. This is one of the more intelligent alien invasion films of the 1950s, the other is This Island Earth (1956). Though the dialogue occasionally is awkward, it presents a complex character in Mr. Johnson, who wants to solve the radiation poisoning of his planet Deranna, resulting from long nuclear wars. However, he is a lone agent who cannot confide with anyone. He uses his eyes to kill others, and then extracts their blood for testing. He uses telepathy, telepathic mind control, and other methods to control others. For awhile he seems to be simply an investigative agent attempting to solve his planet's blood problem, but after awhile the film degenerates to portray a one-dimensional psychopathic alien chasing women in peril -- and the alien dies in car crash -- burned to death. Irony that he suffers the same fate of the victims he killed and then incinerated in a furnace in the cellar. How did he obtain such a luxurious house? And that enormous Cadillac? He could have had a sympathetic partner in the blood bank who was treating him and with whom he shared information of his degenerative blood disease, but late in the film he sent a vampire bat that smothered that other doctor. Or, he could have had the nurse who stayed with him as a sympathetic ear. She treated him and tended to him. But apparently Mr. Johnson could not trust anyone and he became paranoid and violent when the doctor and nurse learned too much. The catalyst came when a woman alien also came through the portal. She reported to him the latest disasters in Deranna -- the war, the captures, the failures of the samples and human subjects to transit safely through the transit beam -- they were crushed. So she said that she would have to stay on Earth -- transport from Earth to Deranna did not work. Only Deranna to Earth worked. She needed a transfusion of blood, but Mr Johnson gave her a transfusion of blood filled with rabies-- by mistake I assume. Perhaps that made him snap. Or, the fact that the doctor discussed the case with the nurse on the phone (with Johnson listening in). Now the nurse knew he was an alien-- then he became violent, killing the houseboy, chasing the nurse through a park, killing a police officer. Finally, another police officer was chasing Mr Johnson and the car crashes, burning Mr Johnson. Ends with an obelisk memorial saying This Man Was Not of This Earth, with the nurse and the police officer talking about the alien. And then appears another agent from Deranna to continue the work--hopefully with better results. The film seems to have a sympathetic alien, but this idea falls apart. Also it comments on the folly of nuclear war. An idea done cbetter with This Island Earth where alien also are suffering from a long nuclear war and they come to Earth looking for help. Other examples of this type are The Day The Earth Stood Still, Starman, The Man Who Fell to Earth. This is Roger Corman's best film, Says The Overlook Encyclopedia of Film: Science Fiction, it is a complex work, showing the alien in shades of gray instead of a one dimensional alien threat. Halliwell likes it, and it is found in most books about science fiction.WAR OF THE SATELLITES (1958) The title is a misnomer. A series of space ships are sent into space but are destroyed by a barrier set up by aliens. The film has been compared to Kronos and The Day the Earth Stood Still, but a faint hint of Invasion of the Body Snatchers, too. It lacks the artistry of The Day the Earth Stood Still. A tenth rocket is planned, this time with the chief scientist aboard. The film is really not all that bad, until the end when during the voyage when Van the captain & scientist leader starts murdering the other crew members for little reason. The aliens set up this barrier and then sent a warning message (in Latin) to stay out of space-- humans are too primitive. Then the alien race causes a car crash of the scientist and makes duplicates of the scientist. This doesn't make sense. As the preparations continue, the alien keeps making more copies of Van. The alien first tries to cancel the mission, then continues it, like he can't make up his mind. Finally the mission begins, the crew is assembled, but already one of the crew suspects Van is an alien (his cold manner, seeing him duplicate himself, etc.). Three rockets go up, with three crews, these merge in a rendezvous and form a spherical space ship-- perhaps the most unusual aspect of the film was the space ship being assembled in space. It is when they are in space that Van the alien strangles on crewman, then conducts a funeral, and later kills the ship's doctor just after he created a heart within himself so the doctor can confirm he is human. Yet after the doctor hears he has a heart (which he just made within himself) Van decides to kill the doctor. And the plans they create to break the barrier also make no sense at all. How the breaking of the barrier is done is never explained. It is a film I actually did like. Not really so bad, though the special effects are awful. Also it is interesting they had a woman scientist astronaut aboard -- way back in the 1950s Other films with women as crew members include Rocketship X-M (1950), Project Moonbase (1953), Flight to Mars (1953), and perhaps others. While other compare this to Kronos, I do not see the parallel.
summary: Mixed bag of cult science fiction

reviewText: OH Yeah! Now this is the way to do it! Put out a set of vintage sci-fi films with really good restored prints, uncut and add commentary, interviews with the director, cast and crew!..all for a very reasonable price.Roger Corman a master of low budget, but very smart and effective films, put out some of the best sci-fi stories of the time period. The first film on this set is 'Attack of the Crab Monsters', which is a much smarter film than the title might suggest. A group of people are stranded on an island where members of the group are mysteriously vanishing. Of course the FX are campy on a budget like this, but the story is quite interesting.The second film which share the single sided disc one is 'Not of this Earth', this is a film that I wasn't too familiar with, but found the story about an alien "vampire"  to be a very good one. The first disc has a 12 minute interview with Corman and while it isn't long, it is very entertaining and informative. There are some TV prologues for each film which I found a little redundant.The second disc holds a single film ' War Of The Satellites' which is the least of the three films because I found it to be a bit talky. It does pick up in the second half and is certainly worthy viewing of any Corman fan. This disc has a nice interview with cast members from the films and Corman. The second disc also has 25 Corman trailers which look really good, not the usual battered to death prints we're used to seeing. Sure there is some wear, but they look very good and it's a nice little touch to this top notch sci-fi set.If you love old sci-fi and or Corman, this is a no brainer  BUY IT ALREADY!
summary: CLASSIC CORMAN! GREAT SET FOR SCI-FI AND CORMAN FANS!
Title: N/A

reviewText: These were never Academy Award quality films to begin with; they were made on a miniscule budget and rushed through production.  But they succeeded where others managed to fail:  they were well made schlock, entertained the audience, and made money.  Something many other "better" movies of the time couldn't do.  Roger became a master of this genre and introduced the business and us to many then unknown talents who have become very well known through the years.  I bought this solely for 'Attack of the Crab Monsters' which by itself seems to have become almost impossible to find.  This has got to be one of the more demented Corman flicks - telepathic crustaceans!!!  If you love funny/weird movies and somehow haven't seen this turkey (smile) you owe yourself the treat.  Quit stalling - go get the popcorn, now.Transfer and sound quality more than adequate for the source material.

reviewText: But great fun. These are three "thrillers" from the days of Chiller Theater and Movie of the week. The effects are corny and the plots are B grade ... but they are great entertainment never-the-less.For a person such as myself who grew up in the fifties and sixties, these are nostalgic memories of my childhood and some of the great times I had watching these pictures with friends. I had an old portable black and white television set in those days and used to make a covering out of a blanket to make a small movie theater. I and my best friend (who would sleep over) would watch these shows on Chiller Theater.For the younger crowd ... well, they may not have any fond memories of these pictures (unless their mother or dad had them on VHS while they were growing up), but they are still good fun. I always enjoyed the plot of the Crab Monsters ... that of the crab eating its victim then luring the next with memories and the voice of the first. Again, very hokey, but tremendously entertaining.And the other two films are just as entertaining. So for 13 bucks, plus shipping, you can enjoy three old time favorites from the middle of the 20th century. The heyday of the B monster movie.Technically speaking, these disks (there are two in the jacket) are clear and sharp (be warned, they are black and white like the original). Sound is good, too. There are some special features for each movie .... the syndicated prologues. They show some scenes which, for whatever reason, were not included as part of the main film in the set. These prologues are slightly out of focus and of lesser quality than the main movie, but that should not matter to anyone since the film itself is of top rate transfer. Also included is an "interview" (discussion really) with Roger Corman and his actors and a large listing/previews of other Corman movies.All in all, for this price and for three films, you just can't get a better deal. True, they are not Indiana Jones or Harry Potter .. and you'll laugh at the monster, but they are entertaining. And after all, isn't that what we buy them for.Strongly recommended for B movie fans.~P~

reviewText: This is a must have for fans of Roger Corman. The movies are some of the earliest and were done on nickle budgets.All 3 films come with good commentary and extras. Title: N/A

reviewText: I waited to read reviews before I ordered. I did, and am more than satisfied. The history of independent film probably was brought to the modern sensibilities via Ed Wood, and his failure. Here we have Roger Corman, an innovator, and some really good prints of films that were thought as lost; Shout Entertainment has delivered a package that makes a 50's trash-film junkie like me scream with joy. The lowest budget-type film is Crab Monsters; War of the Satellites is literate and fun; the best of all is Not of This Earth, a smart story, and creepiest of the bunch. Beverly Garland is the best scream queen ever. I look forward to any future release from the Shout company. They have taken care to present a quality product, which can only encourage them to continue. The Nicholson estate has a hold on some of the best AIP/Corman films, like It Conquered the World and Invasion of the Saucermen. They'd better let loose, or the audience who really appreciates this stuff will all be dead. Thanks, Shout...

reviewText: These movies take me back to Friday Night late movies on the UHF channel in the Bay Area in the 60's and 70's.  Great Cinema ?  No - of course not - but fun, and surprisingly well done ( "Not of this Earth" was particularly well conceived and way above a typical B movie )-  I'll be happy to purchase more of these combo sets -

reviewText: As the (suitably modified) old saying goes, "There are two kinds of people in the world--those who like Roger Corman movies, and those who don't." Well, actually, I think there is a third kind: "Those who are not familiar enough with Roger Corman movies to know whether they like them or not." Put me into this third group.My introduction to Roger Corman movies was the incredibly lame, unbelievably bad "Starcrash," which I bought simply because I had never seen it, and it got many very positive reviews. Strike one. Then I bought the double feature "Up From The Depths/Demon Of Paradise," which I had also never seen before. While marginally better than "Starcrash," these two "Jaws" wannabes were also pretty much stinkers, with nothing to recommend them except for a bit of gratuitous female nudity. Strike two. At the same time, again because of highly positive reviews, I picked up "Attack of the Crab Monsters/War of the Satellites/Not of This Earth," and I finally realized why Roger Corman's films appeal to many people.If you're already familiar with these three films (I was not), it should be a no-brainer for you to pick up this set. The black-and-white transfers are spectacular, the sound quality is excellent and the commentaries and interviews are icing on the cake. Many people have commented that there have been no quality versions of these movies ever available. Shout Factory has now corrected that situation with a truly outstanding package. If you're a fan of old science fiction movies and have not seen these films, I recommend you give this set a try. You may be, as I was, pleasantly surprised.My four-star rating reflects the fact that "Attack of the Crab Monsters/War of the Satellites/Not of This Earth" are nowhere near the quality of bona fide five-star films such as "Forbidden Planet," the original "The Day the Earth Stood Still" or "Them!." But they are pretty good for what they are--low-budget quickies--and they make no pretense of being something they are not. You can look forward to a few hours of enjoyable entertainment with this set.

reviewText: Released from Shout Factory under the "Roger Corman's Cult Classics" collection, this triple feature set is sure to please fans that have waited years to see these classic films in all their black and white glory. The three films are presented on two discs for the first time with all new video transfers from the original film negatives and the video image doesn't disappoint. The picture on all three films is outstanding to say the least and the sound is crisp and clean. I would love to see these films today, one after the other on a big theater screen the way they were meant to be.Fans of Roger Corman and Sci-Fi/Horror fans in general now have three more reasons to shout! That's right, thanks to the amazing people at Shout Factory fans can definitely throw away their worn out VHS and Bootleg copies of "Attack of the Crab Monsters" "War of the Satellites" and "Not of this Earth" All three films are finally presented together in beautiful Black and White, it doesn't get any better than that.This two disc set from Shout is fantastic to say the least and any Roger Corman or Sci-Fi fan will want to have it in their collection. The first disc contains "Attack of the Crab Monsters" and "Not of this Earth" The second disc contains "War of the Satellites" and the incredible Bonus Features Shout included for this DVD release. Make no mistake these three films are sure to entertain, but the bonus features are some of the best I've ever seen included in any DVD release. The two discs are single sided and the disc artwork and packaging is well done. This is another great DVD release from the people at Shout!Attack of the Crab Monsters: a group of scientists marooned on an island investigate the disappearance of fellow researchers who were looking into atomic activity in the Pacific. What form of terror will they really discover?Not Of This Earth: An alien pretending to be a human comes to Earth to search the planet for a new blood source. The alien needs samples of blood from humans to take back to his planet in order to save his dying race. Will the alien be successful in his quest for human blood?War of the Satellites: War is declared against the Earth from a galactic source when the United Nations disobeys warnings while attempting to build the first satellite in outer space. Can the Earth escape destruction?Bonus DVD Features Include:* A Salute To Roger Corman - featuring new interviews with Roger Corman, Peter Fonda, Peter Bogdanovich, Joe Dante and many more.* Audio Commentaries on "Attack of the Crab Monsters" and "Not of this Earth" the (1957) classic with Tom Weaver, John Brunas and Mike Brunas* Authors of Universal Horrors* The Roger Corman Trailer Collection featuring over 25 trailers produced and directed by Roger Corman

reviewText: Well, All three films are in top condition. SHOUT Fatory has done a superb job with the prints as well as the extras.Always a Tom Weaver admirer, here Tom is joined by John and Mike Brunas, Authors of Universal Horrors. It's a lively commentary full of wit and informative historical information on both Attack Of The Crab Monsters and Not Of This Earth. Tom is especially hilarious with some of his stories.Great documentary as well. I won't spoil who appears, suffice to say it it well worth the admission!
summary: Buy It Now And Travel Back In Time

reviewText: I remember seeing these movies, just like everyone else watching thriller at 11:00 pmSaturday night. But,what I remember most was talking about them the next day. We adored these little films and would stop at nothing to watch them. Yes, we are talking about all of these films from "Not Of This Earth" to Attack of the 50 foot women" to even the Killer Shrews.It is also a joy to see these films uncut and in pristine shape, thank you Shout Dvd for this professional job. Thousand of dollars have been spent on bootleg copies to poor transfers of all of these films and now justice has been done. Great Job! There are still a large library of films to be corrected and copied from the original negatives and put on DVD for the fans to enjoy. Roger Corman is the Master of the genre and these little films of excellence is what we have been waiting for. Thank YouWalter Goodseal Jr. The Movie Protector

reviewText: Vintage Science Fiction and Horror fans have cause to celebrate with this magnificent release from Shout Factory.  Over the years, movie auteurs and critics have raved about Roger Corman's Poe Films with Vincent Price but back in the fifties he was cutting his directing chops with over a dozen low budget genre films which the ones included in this set are among his best and rarest.  All these titles have never seen the light of day in pristine negative transfers in both 16mm film or Video tape. Now in the digital age, our wish has come true. Not only do you have these films looking as they must have on the big screen over fifty years ago  , you have an incredible array of extras including a brand new interview with the master plus a tribute documentary with comments by the people who worked and knew him in the business and a collection of over 25 trailers of his best work.  The piece de resistance is audio commentaries on 'ATTACK OF THE CRAB MONSTERS' and 'NOT OF THIS EARTH' by three great Film Historians who I had the honor and pleasure of knowing over twenty years ago, Tom Weaver and the Brunas brothers Michael and John who I lovingly remember joining them scrambling over each others basements back in the day to see a 16mm print of 'WAR OF THE SATELLITES' and treating it like the second coming.  These men know their stuff and boy, do I miss them and their incredible candor and wit.  Shout Factory has released the first important release of this year and every genre fan owes it to themselves to include these great guilty pleasures in their collections.  And where else can you see two of the most underrated actresses of their generation : Beverly Garland and Susan Cabot  strutting their stuff and making you quiver with their beauty and intelligence which always made mince meat of their leading men and made you believe the words they had to recite from the scripts meant so much more then their mediocre surroundings.  Highly recommended.
